title: GIGA selfie allows you to capture the landscape AND your face in a video clip
text:
89 shares 11

Tourism Australia has developed a new app which allows tourists to 'super size' their selfies.
The app, called the GIGA selfie, which has been added to Tourism Australia's Japan site, will put cameras at famous spots around Australia to allow tourists to take pictures of themselves and the surrounding scenery from up to 111 metres away.
Tourists will stand on a 'shooting spot' and then use the 'GIGA Selfie' app on their smartphone to take a photo of themselves, while also prompting a photograph taken from a distant camera.
Scroll down for video
The straightforward selfie has now been given a new twist
The new 'GIGA Selfie' app on the smartphone prompts a distant camera (pictured) to capture the person and the surrounding landscape
Now you can take your selfie and include the surroundings as tourism Australia has developed a new app which allows tourists to 'super size' their selfies
The photo takes the regular concept of a selfie but enlarges it to include the landscape around you (pictured)
In fact the same selfie can even include the landscape from 110 metres away (same tourist now circled in red)
'To take their enormous selfie travellers stand on a designated shooting spot and then use the 'GIGA Selfie' app on their smartphone to prompt a distant camera to capture them and the surrounding landscape,' Tourism Australia explained.
'A link is then emailed to the photo taker and they can share their image as a short video clip which starts as a close up selfie and pulls back to reveal their location.'
The inspiration behind the concept started when it was found that Australia's sixth largest inbound visitors were from Japan - and their favourite form of photography was the selfie.
The GIGA selfie takes a picture of a person from 111 metres away and can be triggered with the touch of a button on your smartphone
A podium will be placed in iconic places around Australia, for people to take the GIGA selfies with their phones just like these two tourists are doing
The GIGA Selfie can then show the landscape around the two tourists
And when it pulls back to the full 110m it shows that the two tourists are actually at the 12 Apostles on the Great Ocean Road in Victoria (circled in red)
Tourism Australia Managing Director John O'Sullivan said that 'the campaign was a chance to capture the renewed enthusiasm for Australia among Japanese travellers.'
'Japan has long been an important tourism market for Australia, with more than 320,000 Japanese visitors travelling here in the past year alone,' said Mr O'Sullivan.
Japanese tourists have also been said to contribute 'more than $1.4 billion in visitor spend he confirmed.
The new app is aimed specifically at Japanese tourists who visit Australia and use selfies. One minute the tourists are up close...
... the next they can be seen in the distance (circled in red) surrounded by an iconic piece of Australia
Now you see them: To take their enormous selfie travellers stand on a designated shooting spot and then use the 'GIGA Selfie' app
Now you don't! A distant camera then captures the tourists (circled in red) and the surrounding landscape
The GIGA selfie campaign hopes to help raise the level of conversation about Australia in Japan and in-turn help to encourage more Japanese travellers to follow in others foot-steps.
This new campaign is being promoted across a wide range of mediums across Japan including digital media, TV, newspapers and travel agency activities.
The first two opportunities to take a huge selfie will be in Queensland off the Gold Coast on September 5 and 6, from 11 am to 4 pm. Future locations are yet to be determined but will be updated through social media outlets.
